5086697.trustfund:
TF026299-PHRD-HUMAN CAPITAL PROTECTION
            (CASH TRANSFERS) AND SOCIAL SECTOR ADJUST
5086697.majtheme: Public sector governance,Human development,Social protection and risk management

repnme.cdata!: Colombia - Social Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Sector Adjustment Loan
            Project, a one-tranche loan intended to be completed before
            the end of the current Administration on August 7, 2002, is
            the Bank's response to the current government's
            demonstrated commitment to social sector reforms. The loan
            will encourage and enable the current Administration's
            momentum on several key social reforms that have been
            developed with active Bank support; b) provide an
            opportunity to influence the social sector agenda of the
            next Administration; and c) help sustain the
            government's fiscal program during this calendar year.
            The loan supports the medium term strategic framework
            including: the introduction of a system of periodic
            impact/performance evaluation and public monitoring of the
            government's main social sector programs to improve
            their transparency and citizen's oversight; the
            development of a comprehensive Social Risk Management
            System, improvements in ICBF (Colombian Institute for Family
            Welfare) child assistance programs, and formulation of a
            time-bound action plan to eliminate barriers to internally
            displaced population's access to social program; the
            expansion of the subsidized health insurance coverage of the
            poor; and improvement of the public education regulatory
            framework, establishment of performance and monitoring
            agreements between the national and selected local
            governments, and more effective dissemination of information
            regarding educational methodologies to improve the education
            of the poor.

1944186.trustfund:
TF026299-PHRD-HUMAN CAPITAL PROTECTION
            (CASH TRANSFERS) AND SOCIAL SECTOR ADJUST

repnme.cdata!: Colombia - Social Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, ratings convey satisfactory
            outcomes, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts. Lessons point at the
            Integrated Social Protection Support, part of a continuum of
            actions implemented by the Government in the social, with
            support from the Bank, through previous, and expected sector
            work, adjustment loans, and investment operations. This
            support created the conditions for the rationalization, and
            integration of social protection functions, and to improve
            effectiveness of service delivery to poor, and vulnerable
            populations, particularly, the internally displaced
            populations. The project focused on appropriate structural
            reforms which the Government was willing to implement to
            improve the institutional underpinnings of the social
            sector. Such was the case of the consolidation of the health
            sector reform (Law 100 of 1993), creating the insurance
            system for the poor (subsidized regime), which the
            Government was willing to rapidly expand. Strategic choices
            and trade-offs are required, particularly in the design of a
            sector adjustment loan, which must balance the establishment
            of policy conditions, with a realistic assessment of the
            expected objectives and what can be accomplished in the
            available timeframe. The project thus benefited from a
            smaller number of conditions, and prioritization of those
            conditions, facilitating preparation and follow-up
            activities. Nevertheless, specific output or target
            indicators should be considered to evaluate the long-term
            impact of reforms in selected social protection programs,
            and services provided to the poor, and vulnerable
            populations. The fast-track timing of this operation led to
            a focus mainly on process, and input indicators, preventing
            the inclusion of measurable outputs as conditions. Further
            lessons suggest that project design would benefit from a
            prioritization of identified problems in the Policy Matrix
            (though with a limited focus on inputs and processes in such
            Policy Matrix), so that only when major reforms are
            operational, would a discussion of indicators be appropriate.
